5.text:
I'm Nicholas Serota and I have been director
of the Tate since 1988. I think that when

14.text:
we decided to create Tate Modern we had first
of all the ambition of creating in London

19.text:
a Museum of Modern Art. I mean there we were
towards the end of the 20th century, one of

23.text:
the few capital cities in the world that didn't
have a Museum that was dedicated to modern

27.text:
art. I mean when I first used to talk about
Bankside to people as a site for Tate Modern,

34.text:
people would say well where is that, people
were not visiting Bankside. Although of course

39.text:
in the 16th century it had been the centre
of the theatre district, it's now I would

43.text:
say a better place than most other cities
in Europe and nearly as good as New York - you

49.text:
can't see quite as much art in a day in London
as you can in New York. My earliest memories

58.text:
are probably memories of being on the Heath,
Hampstead Heath - playing games, chasing girls,

68.text:
enjoying been in the open air and it was an
amazing place to be in London. There are certain

77.text:
art works that somehow evoke personal memories
of being in London at different times and

86.text:
if I think about the rather bleak works that
Gilbert and George made in the 1970s in East

91.text:
London it reminds me of what it felt like
to arrive in East London as I did in 1976

97.text:
as Director of the Whitechapel. To take another
rather more elegiac reference, you go to Primrose

104.text:
Hill, I can't be on Primrose Hill without
thinking of Frank Auerbach's amazing series

108.text:
of paintings recording Primrose Hill as different
times of the year, different seasons, different

114.text:
times of the day, under different weather
conditions so yes of course as I wander around

119.text:
London I see it as it's been seen through
the eyes of painters, sometimes filmmakers.

124.text:
I think the great thing about galleries is
that they ought to be places where people

129.text:
don't feel afraid of going into and when they
go in they'll open themselves up to the experience

135.text:
and perhaps find something they hadn't been
expecting. I wasn't especially good at Art

140.text:
and I didn't pursue it - I became more interested
in History and Geography and Economics which

148.text:
is what I studied initially at Cambridge.
I knew I wasn't going to be a brilliant economist

153.text:
and I thought I would spend two years studying
a subject which even if I didn't pursue it

159.text:
in my professional life would stay with me
for the rest of my life and it caught me unawares
